segments.text: And we went back to the hospital and we did the surgery.
They stayed here in town in a motel until the surgery was over.
Then they flew out.
And then later when the dog recovered, they flew back in.
And they own Harry and David's Orchards in the state of Washington.
I guess the largest fruit shipping company in the whole US.
Now most of these were canine?
Most were canine.
I did some feline.
And I did a few exotics.
Such as?
I did a Bengal tiger once, which was a real challenge.
But I didn't go in the surgery room until he was under anesthesia.
From where did he come?
It was from a zoo.
Okay.
And why here?
Because we had developed that specialty and they knew to call here and that we had the capabilities to handle that kind of animal.
Now, surely there must have been some goofy situations or something.
Oh, there were a lot of fun times that we had.
One time, I'll never forget this.
We had, back in the surgery recovery area, we had these small cages where they would recover from anesthesia.
And we had done surgery on a little chihuahua that probably weighed three or four pounds.
And he was in his cage and already recovered and was on his feet.
And one of the students went over to the large animal clinic
and got a whole little bowl of horse apple feces and came in and put it in the cage with that little bitty chihuahua, giving the impression that he had deposited that enormous amount.
And of course that brought the house down.
And I will never forget one other thing that happened when I was a faculty member.
There was a professor here that taught business law named Judge Stewart.
And he was a character, and I had had him for jurisprudence when I was a veterinary student.
And he was salty, but probably the most entertaining professor I ever had.
But everybody's kind of afraid of him, and he couldn't drive because I think he'd had his license revoked, because he liked the bottle a little.
But his wife brought their cat,

to the small animal clinic and that cat got out of the cage when the student was taking it out and got behind the cages and they could not get the cat out and she was at the front desk to take that cat home.
So everybody was running around there so fearful of what he would do and you know they could just see him coming out there and blowing up and lawsuit and what all might happen.
And it took two or three days to get that cat out from behind that cage.
Any glamorous Texans pets that you had to deal with?
Governors, politicians, board members, coaches, millionaires?
We did have
And I don't, this was after I came back though, after going to the University of Tennessee.
We had Bumbright's dog.
I don't recall any major ones at that time.
And in doing this surgery, you had students as a learning experience for them who were assisting you?
In the teaching hospital,

Not only did, of course, the students have the lectures and the laboratories where they practiced, but then when they were assigned hospital duty rotations, they would rotate among the different disciplines such as anesthesiology, emergency medicine, and mine was neurosurgery.
And we usually had four students assigned to us for an entire week.
Those four students would work with us on every one of our cases from the time we admitted them
through all the diagnostics, to the time of surgery, to the time of recovery.
And of course they would inherit cases that were in different stages of their hospital stay.
And the students would be responsible for the medical records.
Ultimately I was as the attending doctor.
But the student had to write it up.
They gave the medications, recorded it.
They were responsible for
calling an owner and giving them an update.
They scrubbed in in surgery.
They would take turns in doing that.
They would watch anesthesia.
And just the whole care that would happen.
And if they had to stay all night, it was their responsibility to stay all night with their patient.
And they were given a certain assignment for a specific number of cases.
So they stayed a week with us.
And you get to know

people pretty pretty closely in that kind of week's period of time and they knew what the grading criteria would be for that week so every week I had to sit down with a grading card that had a set number of criteria based upon clinical skills background knowledge just the whole spectrum of
responsible teaching activities that we had toward them to see if they would pass it.
And normally on one of those surgeries about how long did the surgical process take?
That varied but I would say I was a fast surgeon and most of the time
My procedure from incision to closure was no more than 20, 30 minutes.
If it was a complicated case, such as a fractured back where I had to go in and put steel plates or something, those could take up to two hours.
Most of the time, not much more than an hour, hour and a half.
If it were a brain surgery, which we did a number of those, brain tumor, head trauma, those were more complicated and would go an hour, hour and a half.
So from the time the animal was injected to... No, that's actual surgical procedure.
From the time of anesthesia to the time of recovery was probably no less than...
That would probably be an hour and a half to two hours on all of those.
And then would that animal then be capable of walking immediately?
We had to stay with them.
You have to help them.
They're not like a human patient that you can keep on a bed.
A lot of times the students have to hold them because when they start trying to wake, they fall around.
They have to hold them until they get ambulatory.
Once they were ambulatory, then you could
clearly allowed on their own.
And was it normal for them to become ambulatory within a few hours?
Yeah, actually you start lightening the anesthesia as you're closing the skin.
So most of them were ambulatory within two hours after the surgery.
And almost all of these were pets?
They were all pets.
And did you detect in those students much difference between their talents, ambitions, et cetera, than you and your classmates?
No, I wouldn't say that I saw any of that.
I would say that I saw them have
the opportunity to be able to do things that we had not been able to do simply because people were now willing to pay for it.
So they got to do a lot more of the new exciting things.
Of course, that was great for us because here we were implementing a lot of those.
And it was a great time for me career wise because I was getting to pioneer a lot of the neurosurgery that's currently done in the dog and to travel the country.
and give presentations and give continuing education seminars and actually do live surgical demonstrations.
A lot of times we did closed circuit TV.
And this was the cost of this was paid for by the owner.
So it was self-sustaining.
Self-sustaining.
See, that was one other part of the teaching component was to teach the students the business side of it because the complaints
in almost all medical professions was the students don't know about that business side of it, which is a side of it.
And most of the time when you're going to veterinary college, you just don't want to even face that.
But we had to because the hospital had to sustain itself based on the revenue of the cases.
And we had to teach that as a part of the responsibility.
Now, this was a 12-month year?
Oh, yeah.
And you're here how long in that stretch?
I stayed in that stretch from 1969
March of 1969 to October of 1974.
And then go to?
I went to the University of Tennessee, and I was 32 years old, and that's where I entered administration.
How did that come about?
Well, that's real interesting.
Can you stop
And I get a phone call, and one of the secretaries came down and said, it's an important call from the Colton Party.
So I go down to my office, and I see a doctor who currently is a dean at Michigan State College of Internal Medicine.
And he said, I don't know whether you've heard or not,
But we're starting a new college of veterinary medicine at the University of Tennessee, and I'm going to be the new dean.
And I just wondered if you would have any interest in being head of the small animal medicine and the surgery department.
Well, that almost knocked me on the floor because I thought, my, how is he calling me?
And he said, my wife and I are going to the American Veterinary Medical Association in July in Denver.
And he said, I notice you're on the program to speak.
I said, would you be willing to have breakfast?
So it was one of those things where it was a life goal to get into administration.
And it was the next logical step for me.
I had already been promoted to associate professor in two years.
So I thought, why would they be asking an associate professor
to be a department head.
So I was flattered and we went, my wife and I both, we had breakfast with him.
He told me that he was leaving to go there in August and that he would like for us to fly up and interview in late August.
And he would show me the campus.
He would tell me the plans and what they were going to be doing.
So we flew up there in September, or no, late August of 1974.
And great interview.
And everything just went, I mean, you couldn't orchestrate it to go any better.
And I kept going through my mind, who are all the other candidates
that he is going to be interviewing.
Who are my peers across the nation, much older than me, that he's going to also interview?
And he offered me the job on the spot.

And he said, I know this is a little unusual, but he said, I've made up my mind that the people I want to recruit, and they have given me the latitude of starting this college by selecting my leadership team.
And he said, I want you to come and head up
the small animal medicine surgery department.
Well, I said, well, my wife and I need to go home and think about it.
You know, our families are in Texas.
I have so much loyalty to Texas A&M.
But at the same time, I knew that it was a career opportunity that I had to seriously look at.
So we got home, and we just knew where we were going to go.
And within two days, I called him back, and I said, yes, we will come.
And so in October of 1974, we left and moved up there.
And I was the first person there after the dean was there.
So it was just the two of us for three or four months to start the program from scratch.
And we had the opportunity to build the facilities, to recruit the faculty.
I mean, everything was brand new.
And I later asked him,
because all the other department heads and deans were older than I was.
And incidentally, one was an Aggie, Horace Barron, who had taught in a large animal clinic here.
So later I asked him, I said, Bill, why did you select me for that position?
And he said, well, you don't remember this, but he said, you came to Michigan State and
I think it was February of 1970, and spoke to our state convention.
And he said, I was in the back of the room, and I heard you give your presentation.
He said, I have followed your career ever since.
And he said, I asked one or two people, and he said, I was looking for someone young that could give it the vigor and the vision.
And he said, that's how I got on it.
to where I wanted you to come and do this program.
So that's how we got there.
And you were there how long?
We were there eight years.
As you look back on being a part of starting a new institution, really, what were the most important decisions that y'all made?
I don't think there's any question what the most important decisions that we made
were decisions related to the people that we recruited, not only our leadership, but also our own faculty.
And the great advantage was that we had no deadwood, we had no history, we had no baggage that was behind us, so that we were able to select a leadership team and a faculty
from across the whole country.
And when we brought them in there, we told them what our philosophy would be of teaching, what our philosophy would be on student relations,
what our philosophy would be on service to the state profession.
And if that was not what they agreed to, that was not the place for them.
And it was an exciting time.
I got to recruit 25 faculty in my own department.
I was also in charge of building the whole facilities, which was five and a half acres under roof.
And at my young age, that was, oh man, that was so much fun.
And to be given that opportunity.
And I recruited, in part because of my young age, a very young faculty.
My belief system was that I wanted to look for young budding stars, rose buds blossoming open, and bring them in there and give them the opportunity to excel.
And it's amazing the number of those people who are still there.
In terms of size, enrollment and faculty, when it got into full operation, how did it compare, say, with A&M?
We took 128 students at A&M and we took 80 there.
Okay.
So it was about three-fourths the size.
But for that size state, that was an adequate number.
Is there anything that you all did that in hindsight if you had to do over again you'd change, you wouldn't do?
Anything you learned negatively?

not really I think probably if you were to ask all of us on the leadership team we probably would have done most everything the same way that we did it because we had an advantage we had a Dean who that was his third Dean ship so he pretty well knew the kinds of things that needed to be done
He was a tremendous administrator and a tremendous statesman.
Now, where did I know of him?
He was dean at A&M.
Oh.
He preceded Al Price.
Okay, okay, all right.
And having been dean at Texas A&M and then dean at Michigan State, I think he served a total time on faculty at A&M of 17 years, including part-time as dean, and then 17 years at Michigan State.
and then became dean of the new program there.
What were the key issues, problems, needs of a department head?
Well, I want to tell you that the key needs there ultimately wound up to be financial needs.
That is not a wealthy state.

we would oftentimes find ourselves after the honeymoon was over about the first three years they were on an annual legislative session and it seemed like that we were just always doing budgets and legislative things so the biggest challenge I think that we had quite frankly was the financial support of the institution and that program and we rode out the honeymoon for
the period of time, but then you begin to be looked at like all the other programs.
I think one of the other great challenges of a department head is that you're somewhat in between the higher administration and the faculty.
And in one sense, you represent your faculty to the upper administration, and in another sense, you represent the upper administration back to the faculty.
But for a learning process and

to me an essential qualification for anyone that would go at a higher level than academic administration they need to have worked in a department head role because that's where the academics the students all meet the whole institutional administration before you went up there did you turn to any department head here for advice i talked to a number and i particularly talked to the clinical department heads
about the challenges, the recruitment of faculty, the different things that they thought that I might be facing that I would need.
They all looked at it as a great opportunity for me because they knew my interest in leadership.
And I knew that I was making a great transition in my own career from having here at A&M had the opportunity to travel worldwide almost
and give presentations in scientific papers.
Now I was going to be coming at a young age of only 32 over into the arena of administration where a lot of the accomplishments would no longer be on my academic resume.
I would have to be dependent upon the accomplishments of the people that I led.
So I realized that early, and that was a part of, I think, being able to lead those people in an effective way.

that I understood that from the front end, and I wanted them to understand that, that I was concerned and supportive of the mission that we had to accomplish, but at the same time, I wanted them to be able to excel in their own achievements.
And was your title department head or chairman?
Yeah, it was department head, and I was promoted to full professor with tenure.
Okay.
As department head, how much did you feel you should automatically be bound by the majority opinion of the department compared to your good judgment?
That's an interesting question because in a faculty meeting, the first faculty meeting with all the faculty after I had recruited, I told them, I said, I want us to have

as much discussion and I will be as democratic as I can but you'll have to know right now that I am held accountable and I'm going to make the final decision if I go against what you as a group believe I'm going to tell you why and I'm going to give you my judgment decision of why I'm making it that way
But it was rare that we disagreed for another reason.
We had recruited them to what we wanted to do.
So I didn't have somebody that I inherited that was disgruntled or dissatisfied.
Do you remember any critical decision where there was some disagreement?
Yeah, I do.
And I remember one specific instance where we had a search committee that selected an individual for a specialty area.
And this man was board certified, probably the most qualified individual in America for that particular specialty.
And in my gut, I did not feel that that was the person I wanted.
And I let
their decision be accepted, I later had to terminate that person.
He was an explosion waiting to happen.
He was not tenured?
No.
So you didn't have to go through the hearing or anything like that?
No, thank goodness.
And life in Knoxville compared to here?
Life in Knoxville compared to here was quite a contrast because Knoxville is a city of 200,000 plus it had a double interstate Running through the center of the city.
It's in the mountainous terrain So you only had limited number of traffic arteries and being a country boy and living in Bryan College Station I was not used to
to the kinds of traffic issues that we had to deal with.
That was different people-wise, very similar.
Another thing that was different though, we had the four seasons of the year and beautiful areas in the spring and particularly the fall with the fall leaf color.
And we thoroughly enjoyed it.
It is a wonderful place to live.
And now what was the image of the profession of veterinary medicine and its importance in that state compared to Texas?
It was not as advanced in that state, in part because probably
It was a more rural state than Texas.

And I think that the income levels were higher in Texas, particularly with our major cities, so that veterinary medicine probably was at a little higher sophisticated level in Texas than it was there.
But we elevated that immediately because we knew that that would be one of our missions
And with the dean being a consummate professional and having a professional image, he was able to do that starting at the state legislative level and all the way down.
And we did it through the university.
And we gained quick acceptance and great respect in a hurry.
All right.
And then you come back to A&M when?
Well, that's interesting because I was invited to come back to A&M after I'd only been there two years.
And to take the large medicine, I mean, the department, which was very large, of medicine and surgery and break it into two departments.
One would be large animal medicine surgery, the other would be small animal medicine and surgery.
And I would be given the opportunity to build a complete new small animal hospital.
And I can tell you that my heart was to come home.
Our families lived here.
I mean, I loved A&M with all of my heart.
I wanted to come back here.
This is a well-funded program.
They had finances.
They had resources.
But I couldn't do it and be a person of integrity and character because I had been given a trust and a responsibility to help build something there.
And I felt that I owed them at least five or six years.
But I had a confidence in my heart
that at the right time that something would open up for me to come to A&M.

And after we'd been there seven years, it was announced that the associate dean for academic programs, who at the time was Wallace Bay, was going to retire a year in advance and they were going to start searching.
Well, I just began to feel that there was a confidence that that was going to open up for me.
And I knew they'd have to go through this big search process, which they did.
I came.
I went through the interview.
I interviewed with everybody you can dream of and made a presentation to the faculty.
And one part of the presentation was crucial because A&M was the College of Veterinary Medicine and then moving from the three-year curriculum back to a four.
Well, I had just been a part of developing a brand new four-year curriculum.
Plus, I had been a graduate of the three-year and had taught on the three-year.
So I geared my presentation to what I thought would be a creative concept of moving to that and what I felt were the academic and student responsibilities of the position.
And I was offered the position within a few weeks after I interviewed.
And I had already, in eight years, I had done what I believed I could do there
Plus, I'm one of those people that every five to six years, I need a new challenge.
And this would have been a great challenge.
It was another advancement for me.
And quite clearly, it was coming home.
All right, now you had met this dean that was here before you left.
Wasn't he here?
Yes, but only for I think a few months before I left the University of Tennessee.
So I really did not know him except through the eight years at the University of Tennessee.
I'd always been at the national meetings and I had met him.
I'd gone to the A&M alumni reception and had gotten to know what a fine gentleman that he was.
And as far as you know, was he a factor in making the final decision?
I'm certain it was his decision.
The search committee, I know, made their recommendation and then it was, I'm sure, his decision.
His consultation, probably with you, I don't know whether you were still here at the time, but I will tell you one thing.
When I left here to go to the University of Tennessee, a part of this process, you may not remember this,
But you had an exit interview with people who left here.
And I remember you were officed over in the Teague building.
And you asked me to come over and talk to you, which I did.
And I never forgot that.
That meant a lot to me about the administration's concern and just interest in where their faculty members were going.
To me, any time a faculty member left here and went to another university in an advancement, that was really a compliment to A&M.
And I later had to remind deans and department heads of that.
Among things that I believed in then and still do, see, I would try to have
for every prospective faculty member from off campus, I would say to the search department or whatever it might be, give me a half hour.
Under no circumstance will I try to investigate and judge the person.
I want to try to tell them as candidly and as honestly as I can what this institution is and what it hopes to become.
They may not like what we are.
They may not.
Then the other one was to try to find out, as tactfully as I could, is there anything that is a factor in this person's leaving that we maybe need to know about that I might learn.
In those initial interviews, I discovered one guy
I mentioned he had his Ph.D. from Virginia.
I mentioned going over to work, and I gave the name of the library.
And I realized, you know, I'm Hunt, and I mentioned it.
Oh, oh, oh, yes, yes.
I thought, hmm.
I then made up three people's names in his supposed area, and he knew them all well.
I then called the department and I said, you need to check.
Something didn't work.
They called that department at
Virginia.
They had never heard of him.
His resume was a fraud.
Make believe I didn't know George Shelton well.
Describe George Shelton.
George Shelton was probably the most gracious human being I have ever worked with in my life.
And George was a person who, when he gave you a responsibility, it was yours.
I never will forget once I told George, I said, George, you're almost too nice to be a dean.
To never ruffle the feathers of anyone.
